text: Ita Marija Kozakeviča (3 July 1955 - 28 October 1990) was a Latvian Polish philologist, journalist and social worker. Born in Riga, she was a graduate of Latvian State University, specializing in French Philology, she later worked in publishing as an editor, journalist, and translated numerous works, being able to speak Latvian, French, Russian, Polish, Spanish, German, Belarusian, Ukrainian and Georgian. In 1988 she was elected as President of the newly established Union of Poles in Latvia, and was one of the Latvian SSR People's Forum organizers in December 1988, which later became the Latvian National Culture Societies Association. In 1989 she elected as a board member of the City Council of Riga, and was elected to the Supreme Council of the Republic of Latvia, representing the Popular Front of Latvia, where she was responsible for human rights issues. On 28 October 1990, while visiting Italy Kozakēviča drowned swimming in the Tyrrhenian Sea off the town of Gaeta, two days before she was due to meet the Pope at the Worldwide Polish Society Conference at the Vatican. She was buried at St. Michael Cemetery in Riga. ==References== Category:1955 births Category:1990 deaths Category:Writers from Riga Category:Latvian people of Polish descent Category:Popular Front of Latvia politicians Category:Deputies of the Supreme Council of the Republic of Latvia Category:Latvian philologists Category:Women philologists Category:Latvian journalists Category:Latvian women writers Category:Latvian human rights activists Category:20th-century Latvian women writers Category:20th-century Latvian writers Category:University of Latvia alumni Category:Deaths by drowning Category:20th-century journalists
